channel.title: Reflections on Hareesh Kanchanepally
channel.description: Recent content in Reflections on Hareesh Kanchanepally

item.title: Week notes, S3E6: 03 - 09 Feb, 25
item.description:
Theme: Consolidation, Connection, and Tiny Steps #

Another week ticked by. February’s gaining momentum, and it feels like a time for both consolidation and intentional movement. This week has been about bringing things into focus, both at work and at home.

At work, it’s been a week of clarity through consolidation. Sometimes, the sheer volume of projects can feel like a fog. This week was about cutting through that, taking a portfolio-level view. Status, risks, resources – getting it all down, sorting it out. It’s the unglamorous but essential work of leadership. The prep work that allows for deeper conversations. That conversation happened with product leadership this week, surfacing key decisions, pushing forward on crucial areas. Still more to do, always, but feeling like we cleared some ground and defined the path ahead, even if just a little. And equally important, connecting with the teams on the ground, understanding their perspectives, aligning intentions on how we work. It’s the connection that matters as much as the plan.

item.title: Jan 2025 Summary | Monthnotes
item.description:
January Reflections & February Intentions: Setting the Course for the Year

January. The first page turned in a new chapter. It’s been a month of looking both inwards and outwards, taking stock, and starting to set the course for the year ahead. As is my practice, I’ve been using the “Wheel of Life” as a framework to reflect across different areas – work, finances, health, relationships, personal growth, and more. Here’s a snapshot of January and a peek into what I’m aiming for in February.

item.title: Week notes, S3E3: 13 - 19 Jan, 25
item.description:
Theme: Finding Balance in Tension #

Tension is a constant in life. Whether it’s the pull between ambition and patience, work and family, or even silence and words—it’s always there. This week was about learning to navigate those tensions with grace and clarity, even when things felt overwhelming. What I realise is that while intent is and was there, the day-to-day structures and pressures - and as I wrote last week - the foundations matter so much. The key learning is that the foundations need to give space for the unexpected and also the life-long habits and charecteristics that make us individuals.

item.title: Week notes, S3E2: 06 - 12 Jan, 25
item.description:
Theme: Laying Steady Foundations #

New beginnings are exciting, but they’re also delicate. The second week of the year wasn’t about grand leaps forward—it was about setting the groundwork, brick by brick, for what’s to come. The focus was on building clarity, momentum, and alignment—both at work and home.

Work: Clarifying the Blueprint
At work, the new year began in earnest, and with it, the complexity of a programme that spans two PMOs, each with overlapping accountabilities. RACI models are great on paper, but when two sets of leaders and structures coexist, clarity doesn’t emerge without effort. The week was dedicated to mapping out roles and responsibilities and ensuring alignment across teams. It felt less like a sprint and more like laying steady planks across a gap, one meeting and one conversation at a time.

item.title: Week notes, S3E1: 30 Dec, 24- 05 Jan, 25
item.description:
Theme: Making Space #

New years don’t start with fireworks (well, ours did—with gentle Rainbow crackers to welcome the year); they start with clearing space. Four bags to Oxfam, a trip to the recycling centre, and a freshly deep-cleaned home weren’t just tasks. They were declarations: “This is the past. Now, I’m making room for what’s next.”

But space isn’t only physical. It’s emotional, relational, and mental. Hosting an old friend this week during the new year celebration brought joy, nostalgia—and a bit of tension. Yet, often the best response is to simply hold space. Not everything needs a resolution. Sometimes, it’s enough to just be present.

item.title: On Holding things lightly - Weeknotes: 16 - 22 Sep
item.description: I am reminded of a story I read as a child as I reflect on this last week. Kids were getting terrified of a snake in a field when they want to play there. One day, a sage passed through the field, observes this, and suggests the snake to ease off, and let it share the field with all others. Snake listens, and stops resorting to aggression. Over the next few months, the kids, the passer-bys and others get accustomed to the now insipid snake. Some kids even start using it as a toy, thrashing across the field and so on. Sage – on his return from his travels –passes through the field again and realises the sorry state of the snake. It tells the snake that his advice to her was not to be aggressive and selfish, but he never meant her to become the opposite and become submissive, retired, insipid.

item.title: Week 31 #Weeknotes: Aug 5-9, 2024
item.description:
Work front #

During my last published #weeknotes, I mentioned about doing a 360-degree risk review of my portfolio of programmes and coming up with a list ahead of a leadership offsite. I feel I ought to share that here.

  • Confusion amongst cross-functional delivery vs domain-based organisation structure.

  • Confusion between iterative model of delivery vs stage-gates way of monitoring/governance

  • Lack of end-to-end focus on product delivery from all the disciplines involves.

item.title: Week 27 #Weeknotes: July 8 -14, 2024
item.description:
Despite the ongoing struggle to wrangle weekly updates, I’m back in the saddle again. Persistence, it seems, is the key to consistent victories, both in writing and in life.

Work Front: The Enterprise Software Development Rollercoaster

Persistence rings especially true in my work in product development and delivery. I continue to grapple with a set of issues that, over my 15-year career, feel both repetitive and wicked. These challenges, while engaging and intellectually stimulating, follow a cyclical pattern: a period of rapid development to meet immediate revenue goals, followed by a phase of simplification and unification. Build, then tidy—rinse and repeat.

item.title: Week 20, May 13-19, 2024
item.description:
Another whirl-wind of a week with lots packed in. Let’s jump right-in.

Work #

Generalizations are super easy, and we like to theorize and come up with very assured plans or “solutions” to some of our wicked problems. I am going to generalize a bit now, but by saying how easy it is to do, I ask you to consider this theory with a disclaimer, a caution, and as my opinion, inviting you to share yours. So, here’s my theory about the current problems we face in product development/delivery:

item.title: S2E17 #Weeknotes Apr 22-28 '24
item.description: I am sorry that I missed sharing the last two weeks of weekly notes. A pesky scaphoid fracture and a possible diabetes diagnosis threw a wrench in my plans. While reflecting on this (admittedly with some grumbling!), I realised it’s no excuse to stop sharing. I’m committed to continuing to deliver thoughtful, useful, and enjoyable reflections for my curious readers (if you’re one of them ;-P).

item.title: S2E14 #Weeknotes Apr 01-07 '24
item.description: Luckily, my scaphoid fracture last week didn’t interfere much with the day-to-day. It was nuisance alright, and I did get a couple of bad nights, but apart from the superficial aberration, I was able to carry on. What shone through this whole evolving episode is NHS’s Torbay hospital. The staff, their diligence, the patience despite the hectic Easter weekend has been superb. It would be an organisation that I would love to work with and support their magnificent endeavour.

item.title: S2E11 #Weeknotes Mar 11-17 '24
item.description:
Crikey, this week’s been good, both at the office and at home. Let’s unpack the highlights:

The Work Front

Nearly 5-ish months in the deep end covering for my boss, Vice-President, PMO – what a ride! I’ve been reflecting on the impact I’ve made and how to keep that momentum going across different projects.

Speaking of big-picture stuff, we’ve kicked off the 3-year planning exercise. This is essentially a roadmap for the next three years, helping us chart our course and prioritise initiatives. Companies do this for a few reasons: to anticipate future trends, ensure alignment across departments, and make sure we’re all rowing in the same direction. The process itself usually involves a mix of top-down direction and bottom-up input – think strategy sessions with senior leadership and feedback loops from individual teams.

item.title: S2E10 #Weeknotes Mar 04-10 '24
item.description:
Looking back on the week, it’s been a whirlwind of activity both professionally and personally. Let’s dive into the highlights:

Professional Reflections:

As you know, the economic landscape has been undergoing some seismic shifts lately. With the end of the era of “free money” and the closure of zero interest rate policies, businesses are feeling the squeeze. In the tech industry, where costs often took a backseat to other revenue streams, there’s now a renewed focus on the bottom line. The talk of the town revolves around layoffs, potential recessions, and the need for prudent financial management.

item.title: S2E09 #Weeknotes Feb 26-Mar 03, '24
item.description:
2024 is already rolling, and this past week provided a handful of experiences that will definitely stick with me. Let’s jump right in!

SOFEA and the community spirit: My organisation, Informa, runs a fantastic initiative by offering employees four days of paid volunteer leave to contribute to a cause of their choice. As we began the year, I looked for ways our technical program management team could bond outside of work. Brainstorming another project solution didn’t feel right, so using a day to support a local charity was a clear choice.

item.title: S2E08 #Weeknotes 19-25 Feb'24
item.description:
Meta reflections on writing these #weeklynotes

While the underlying purpose has always been “to reflect on the past week, to go forward into the next week with intentions”, I dabbled with multiple formats for writing these #weeknotes. I might never settle on one format, but I am drawing back on the inspiration from Philippa Perry’s book, “How to Stay Sane”, for the foundational principles: that to remain stable yet flexible, coherent and yet able to embrace complexity, and to thrive in this world, these #weeknotes help me in: a) self-observation, b) relating to others, c) managing stress (as the right kind of stress creates positive stimulation), and d) listening/amending the personal narrative. While I chop the reflections into personal/work boxes, the key themes are the same.

item.title: S2E07 #Weeknotes 12-18 Feb'24
item.description:
Personal Reflections:

It’s gratifying to write for others, and I appreciate your readership. Last week, I started sharing my fortnightly newsletter Des/Pardes more widely. Strangely enough, there’s a duality of feeling: a feeling of self-indulgence balanced by a desire to share/be heard. The positive feedback from readers has been validating, and I’m committed to maintaining consistency while using writing to reflect on myself, the community, and our shared space.

This week also saw a renewed focus on coding practice, spcefically on control structures and efficient error handling. I firmly believe that I have a lot to learn, and I don’t think that drive will never fade. For anyone interested in diving into programming, I would definitely recommend one of the HyperionDev bootcamps (if you sign up from the link, you get a 10% discount too!)

item.title: S2E06 #Weeknotes 05-11 Feb'24
item.description:
Personal Reflections:

This week was a tapestry of personal growth and introspection. Launching my fortnightly newsletter focusing on the first-gen Indian immigrant experience proved daunting. The commitment to a regular cadence felt more intimidating than starting a blog with its flexible schedule. But like any good product manager, I embraced the challenge, navigating the “oscillation and consideration of risks alongside ambitions.” Now, the focus lies on marketing the newsletter and ensuring its value for both myself and my subscribers.

item.title: S2E05 #Weeknotes 29 Jan-04 Feb'24
item.description:
Hi Everyone,

I took a couple of days off from work and spent some time Coding, catching up with Rach, and generally getting ready to launch a newsletter focusing on my experiences as a first-gen expat in a new country. After launching into Jan, taking a couple of days off has been good to get perspective. There’s a general sense that companies are struggling, with the pendulum swinging back from inordinate cash at disposal to profitability and efficiencies. The tightening of belts is healthy, though uncomfortable for some. This leads to a lot of reflection, defensiveness, and even shutting down. I see this in every sphere, and perhaps something we can all do is acknowledge that we’re in this together and need to look after ourselves more.

item.title: S2E04 #Weeknotes 22-28 Jan'24
item.description:
Monday morning musings, chai brewing, and the lingering echoes of weekend reflections – that’s my favourite way to kick off the week. This time, however, the echoes resonate with both professional triumphs and personal introspection. Let’s unpack them.

Work Wins:

This week was a whirlwind of collaboration, strategy, and a dash of healthy assertiveness (something I’m consciously cultivating). Aligned teams, a crystal-clear Researcher valuestream (and its next steps!), and a deep dive into effective release documentation – all in a week’s work! Not to mention tackling the ever-evolving landscape of PMO leadership and interrogating the governance layers that sometimes inadvertently lead us away from the customer. It’s intense, but I’m loving the momentum and the collective progress – feels like we’re finally leaving 2023 in the dust!

item.title: S2E01 #WeekNotes 1-7 Jan '24
item.description:
Key Themes for the week #

  • Common to both professional and personal lives

    • Intentionality

    • Presence

    • Reflection

    • A LOT to do and so little a time ;-P

  • Specifically around personal life

    • Care

    • Gratitude

    • Financial planning and its health

    • Health

    • House improvements

    • Being an immigrant

    • Being a foodie and the link to being immigrant and health habits

  • Specifically around work

    • Prioritisation

    • Longer-term strategies
